page.title: 02LITTLE BYTHAM
page.content: The southern part of Little Bytham lies within this block, about 54 houses in all. The oldest houses are mostly built of local limestone (there are several quarries nearby), roofed with stone slates or pantiles. Later building was done in red brick (from the local brickyard, now closed, or Peterborough), tiled or pantiled. Most recent building has been done in various types of brick. The old nucleus of the village lies west of the railway, with outlying farms to south and east. To the south the narrow strip of land between the railway and the B1176 has gradually been filled in with housing and light industrial premises, almost as far as the old station, opposite which is a pub (formerly the Station Hotel), a factory and some small semi- detached cottages.
